risk_factors.description: Collectively these moves cut the probability of firm-load shed during an 18 °F system-wide cold snap to 12%, half the 2023 risk profile, according to ERCOT’s 2024 State of the Grid report[^5]
Deliveries begin 2026, allowing West Harris County Regional Water Authority members to slash aquifer withdrawals and curb land subsidence that elevates flooding risk[^21]

2  Incremental Expansions From the Permian to Houston

* GCX Compression Expansion: +570 MMcf/d to Agua Dulce by mid-2026, relieving Waha price volatility and increasing molecules available for Houston-area industrial users[^28][^29]

Synthesis and Forward Risks

Houston’s public and private sectors are on pace to invest more than \$20 billion in energy, water and telecom infrastructure between 2023 and 2028—roughly \$2,400 per resident—to future-proof the metro against climate, digital and demographic shocks[^33]

Yet challenges persist:

* **Rate Pressure:** Electric and water impact fees are rising faster than CPI; CenterPoint surcharges plus City water tariff hikes could add \$12-15 monthly to median utility bills by 2027[^1][^34]

* **Supply-Chain Volatility:** Large-diameter pipe and pad-mount transformer lead times remain double pre-pandemic norms, threatening schedule cushions for remaining GHRI and pipeline scopes[^35][^36]
Despite these headwinds, the scale and speed of 2024-25 infrastructure upgrades mark a decisive shift from reactive post-storm patchwork to proactive, integrated capital planning

risk_factors.description:
2  What the Barrier Means for Development

- Bond underwriters now discount storm-surge risk for Port Houston tank-farms by 20 basis-points when the GCPD match is appropriated, lowering borrowing costs for capital-intensive petrochem plants[^23]

3  Ike Dike Alternatives and Gate Design Debates

Local pilots raised navigational concerns about the Corps’ double-sector gate, prompting Texas A\&M’s Institute for a Disaster-Resilient Texas to study arch and barge-gate options in 2024[^25]

Early simulations suggest a wider, single-sector gate could halve dredging costs without sacrificing surge performance—an engineering decision that will influence both construction phasing and real-estate risk maps over the next decade

35 psf roof install | 10-yr GSI tax abatement; energy OPEX savings 10–15% | [^14][^16] |
| Coastal barrier funding uncertainty | Equity hurdle-rate premium 100 bps on surge-exposed sites | Stage land options; track GCPD drawdown schedule | [^24][^28] |

## 6
Taken together, these measures represent a **structural re-pricing of location risk** across Greater Houston

For stakeholders across the property spectrum, from single-family builders to global energy majors, understanding the shifting code base and infrastructure map is no longer optional—it is the key to de-risking investments and sustaining Houston’s momentum through the next century of storms, heat, and coastal change

risk_factors.description:
Pension-Fund Allocations: Quiet but Growing

Houston-area retirement systems upped real-estate targets to buffer equity volatility:

* **Houston Police Officers Pension System (HPOPS)**
    * Added \$15 million to Neuberger Berman Real Estate Secondary Opportunities II; total 2025 pacing \$105 million[^27][^28]
* New strategic asset-allocation (effective Sept 2024) reduces office exposure, reallocates to specialty housing and infrastructure[^30]

* **Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (Houston exposure)**
    * Sold three legacy Houston office towers but injected US\$300 million follow-on equity into Encino Acquisition Partners and co-led an \$800 million U

## Conclusion

The 2024 investment cycle reset Houston pricing yet reaffirmed its core appeal: **port-driven industrial demand, outsized population growth, and a policy toolkit (OZ, Chapter 380, TIRZ) that narrows risk for long-term capital**

risk_factors.description: ** A 2025 state law lets licensed engineers perform plan review when the city fails to act within two business days, after which construction may start immediately—further de-risking timelines[^22]

Carbon-Neutrality Goals and Development Risk

### 5
** Carriers now discount premiums for projects that integrate bioretention and elevated mechanical rooms within 500-year floodplains—an implicit carbon-risk price[^8]

## Conclusion

Houston has moved from aspirational green goals to a layered system of **carrots (tax abatements, C-PACE, 179D)** and **sticks (stricter 2021 codes, flood-risk disclosures, optional EV/solar appendices)** that shape every stage of real-estate development

Projects that design for LEED or GSI, pre-wire for chargers, and integrate rooftop PV can now lower both construction financing costs and long-term operating expenses, while de-risking exposure to future carbon regulations

risk_factors.description:
1 Ranking Frameworks

Children at Risk’s 2023-24 ranking uses STAAR proficiency, year-over-year growth, and college readiness to grade 1,502 Houston-area campuses[^3]

Lamar CISD advanced six slots in Children at Risk’s league table, buoyed by 28% five-year enrollment growth that allowed the district to open two STEM-focused high schools and keep class sizes under 24[^2]

3 Voucher Uncertainty

Although the 2025 Legislature appears set to pass an education-savings-account program, Houston-area heads of school say they lack classroom surplus to absorb a sudden voucher wave and would need several years to expand physical plant[^17]

Pension-Fund Allocations: Quiet but Growing

Houston-area retirement systems upped real-estate targets to buffer equity volatility:

* **Houston Police Officers Pension System (HPOPS)**
    * Added \$15 million to Neuberger Berman Real Estate Secondary Opportunities II; total 2025 pacing \$105 million[^27][^28]
* New strategic asset-allocation (effective Sept 2024) reduces office exposure, reallocates to specialty housing and infrastructure[^30]
** A 2025 state law lets licensed engineers perform plan review when the city fails to act within two business days, after which construction may start immediately—further de-risking timelines[^22]

Carbon-Neutrality Goals and Development Risk

Pension-Fund Allocations: Quiet but Growing

Houston-area retirement systems upped real-estate targets to buffer equity volatility:

* **Houston Police Officers Pension System (HPOPS)**
    * Added \$15 million to Neuberger Berman Real Estate Secondary Opportunities II; total 2025 pacing \$105 million[^27][^28]
* New strategic asset-allocation (effective Sept 2024) reduces office exposure, reallocates to specialty housing and infrastructure[^30]
** A 2025 state law lets licensed engineers perform plan review when the city fails to act within two business days, after which construction may start immediately—further de-risking timelines[^22]
